Literature Review: Bovine colostrum, the first milk produced by cows after calving, is a rich source of bioactive components that have been extensively studied for their health-promoting properties in both veterinary and human medicine. This literature review aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the bioactive components in bovine colostrum, the processing techniques used to produce high-value colostrum-based products, and recent studies utilizing bovine colostrum for health applications. Bovine colostrum contains a wide array of bioactive components, including immunoglobulins, growth factors, antimicrobial peptides, and cytokines, which contribute to its health-promoting effects. Immunoglobulins, particularly IgG, are the most abundant bioactive proteins in bovine colostrum and play a crucial role in passive immunity transfer to newborns, protecting them against infections. Studies have shown that bovine colostrum can enhance immune function, promote gut health, and support growth and development in both animals and humans. The processing of bovine colostrum into functional foods, nutraceuticals, and pharmaceuticals involves various techniques such as pasteurization, freeze-drying, and spray-drying, which aim to preserve its bioactive components while ensuring safety and shelf stability. Recent advancements in processing technologies have enabled the production of high-quality colostrum-based products with enhanced bioavailability and efficacy. In veterinary medicine, bovine colostrum has been used to prevent and treat gastrointestinal infections, support immune function, and promote growth in young animals. In human health, bovine colostrum has been investigated for its potential to enhance immune function, improve gut health, and support recovery from exercise-induced muscle damage. Clinical studies have demonstrated the efficacy of bovine colostrum in reducing the incidence and severity of gastrointestinal infections, improving gut barrier function, and enhancing immune response in both healthy individuals and those with compromised immune systems. Furthermore, bovine colostrum has been shown to have anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, which may contribute to its therapeutic effects in various disease states. Despite the promising health benefits of bovine colostrum, further research is needed to fully understand its mechanisms of action, optimize processing techniques, and establish standardized guidelines for its use in veterinary and human health applications. In conclusion, bovine colostrum represents a valuable natural resource with significant potential for the development of functional foods, nutraceuticals, and pharmaceuticals aimed at promoting health and preventing disease in both animals and humans.
